attributes.title: Fox's Magic: The Gathering Movie Franchise Will Enable Hasbro To Sell Trading Cards For Years
summary: Fox has acquired the movie rights to a 23-year-old trading card game from Hasbro. The focus, though, is on converting moviegoers to gamers.
Hasbro stands to benefit because several generations have fallen in love with the game - and they keep coming back, spending more money.
Magic can easily be compared to the successes of other fantasy- and comic book-related franchises - making once nerdy topics profitable.

attributes.content:
"Movie franchise." Those two words have high-powered many great comic book series, nerd entertainment, and 80s toys across the big screen. Bringing a story to a whole new generation of would-be viewers offers great opportunities to sell more product. Will Magic: The Gathering have the same success for Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS)?

News broke in January 2014 that Fox (FOX) (FOXA) acquired the rights to the movie franchise. The focus of this article is on the benefit that the movie series will have for Hasbro, owner of Magic: The Gathering, produced by wholly-owned Wizards of the Coast. I believe awareness of the movie franchise will bring new customers to Hasbro and reignite previous customers to become customers all over again. This article does not cover the benefits to Fox which owns the movie rights but looks at how an appealing movie might convert viewers into Hasbro customers.

What is the Magic: The Gathering?

Magic: The Gathering, or MTG for short, started as one of the first collectible trading card games (TCG) in 1993 by the immensely talented game designer Richard Garfield. Even after many imitations and some successful competitors (Pokemon and Yu-Gi-Oh!), it is still the number one TCG in the world. Tournaments with hundres of thousands in prize money are held worldwide. Its growth has been immense in a suffering gaming division. Tournament champions are represented from all over the world. The trading cards are printed in 11 languages in over 70 countries. North America and Western Europe are the dominant markets.
